Formal Public Comment on OPM -2025-0004  
Docket ID:  OPM-2025-0004  
Title: Improving Performance, Accountability, and Responsiveness in the Civil Service  
To Whom It May Concern:  
I write to strongly oppose the proposed regulation titled Improving Performance, 
Accountability, and Responsiveness in the Civil Service  (Docket ID: OPM –2025–0004). This 
regulation, which seeks to establish a new "Schedule Policy/Career" classification within 
the excepted service, is a direct threat to the integrity, independence, and democratic 
foundation of the U.S. civil service.  
This proposal is not a minor administrative adjustment; it is a sweeping and dangerous 
transformation of how federal personnel are hired, retained, and dismissed. Below are five 
critical reasons why this rule must be withdrawn.  
1. Erosion of Due Process and Merit Protections  
The proposed regulation, which would create a new “Schedule Policy/Career” 
classification within the excepted service, directly contradicts the foundational principles 
of a merit -based civil service. It would allow thousands of career federal employee s, those 
labeled as “policy -influencing” , to be stripped of the rights and protections afforded under 
Title 5 of the U.S. Code. These individuals could be terminated without cause, without 
notice, and without recourse , removing the procedural safeguards that ha ve long protected 
the integrity of our nonpartisan civil service.  
This is fundamentally at odds with the stated intentions of Executive Order titled Restoring 
Equality of Opportunity and Meritocracy  (April 2025). That EO opens with a powerful 
affirmation:  
“A bedrock principle of the United States is that all citizens are treated equally under 
the law... It encourages meritocracy... not favoritism.” (Sec. 1)  
Further, it underscores the importance of evaluating individuals based on “individual 
strengths, effort, or achievement” and explicitly warns against systems that undermine 
opportunities for individuals to succeed on their own merits:  
“Disparate -impact liability... has hindered businesses from making hiring and other 
employment decisions based on merit and skill...” (Sec. 1)  
Yet this proposed rule moves in the opposite direction. It does not encourage meritocracy, 
but instead replaces it with political discretion. It does not promote equal opportunity, but 
instead allows for arbitrary dismissal based on a shifting and opaque d efinition of “policy 
influence.” This directly undermines the very goal of treating individuals based on “their 
strengths, effort, or achievement.”  
If the administration is sincere in its belief that:  
“Employers should be able to use bona fide job -oriented evaluations when 
recruiting,”  — Section 1, Purpose  
then it cannot support a system in which qualified, experienced, and competent civil 
servants are denied job security , not because of performance or misconduct, but because 
they occupy roles that may be politically inconvenient . 
If the administration is committed to promoting individual merit, equal treatment under the 
law, and protection from arbitrary decision -making, then this proposed rule is an 
undeniable contradiction. The “Schedule Policy/Career” rule removes employment 
protections from qualified, experienced, and loyal civil servants, many of whom have 
dedicated their careers to upholding the law, regardless of political party.  
Rather than advancing meritocracy, this rule promotes ideological conformity by allowing 
for the removal of employees based on perceived political misalignment , turning a system 
grounded in qualifications and expertise into one vulnerable to favoritism and political 
coercion.  
Moreover, the rule would expose many employees to termination simply because they hold 
policy-related responsibilities , not because of poor performance, lack of merit, or legal 
misconduct, but because of where their role sits within an organizational chart.  
The President’s own Executive Order recognizes:  
“Citizens will be treated equally before the law and as individuals, not consigned to 
a certain fate based on their immutable characteristics.” (Sec. 1)  
Yet this regulation, by categorizing certain roles as inherently subject to political will, 
effectively consigns public servants to professional instability and career vulnerability —not 
based on individual merit or misconduct, but based on administrative d esignation and 
perceived policy influence.  
At its core, this rule trades merit for loyalty, skill for silence, and due process for political 
control. It is incompatible with the values enshrined in the American civil service system as 
a whole.  
This is not meritocracy.  
This is not due process.  
And this is not equality under the law.  
The Office of Personnel Management should uphold the merit system principles codified in 
law and reaffirmed by executive action. I urge OPM to withdraw this proposed rule in its 
entirety.  
2. Politicization of the Civil Service  
The proposed regulation grants the President unprecedented authority to unilaterally 
reclassify a wide range of federal positions into a new category  called “Schedule 
Policy/Career”  and effectively stripping those roles of the statutory protections that ensure 
a nonpartisan, merit -based federal workforce. This move would mark a radical shift in the 
civil service system by enabling the wholesale replacement of experienced professionals 
based not on performance or legal violations, but on perceived political alignment.  
This fundamentally politicizes the federal workforce, blurring the essential distinction 
between career civil servants , who are charged with implementing the law faithfully , and 
political appointees, who serve at the pleasure of the President.  
This regulation directly undermines several pillars of U.S. law:  
Title 5 U.S.C. § 2301 – Merit System Principles  
The federal merit system is governed by nine core principles, including:  
1. “Recruitment should be from qualified individuals from appropriate sources in an 
endeavor to achieve a workforce from all segments of society.  
2. “Selection and advancement should be determined solely on the basis of relative 
ability, knowledge, and skills after fair and open competition."  
3. “Employees should be protected against arbitrary action, personal favoritism, or 
coercion for partisan political purposes.”  
Reclassifying policy -influencing roles into an at -will category contradicts every one of these 
principles by removing fair competition, merit -based selection, and protection from 
political coercion.  
Title 5 U.S.C. § 2302 – Prohibited Personnel Practices  
This law explicitly prohibits:  
• “Any personnel action based on political affiliation or conduct.”  
• “Any action that violates merit system principles.”  
Under this rule, civil servants in roles like policy analysis, grant oversight, and scientific 
evaluation could be terminated or reassigned solely because their professional 
recommendations differ from the political objectives of the current administration . This is 
the very type of action Congress sought to prevent when it codified protections against 
political abuse in the civil service.  
Public trust in federal agencies depends on their independence, professionalism, and 
consistency across administrations. This regulation opens the door to loyalty tests, where 
continued employment depends on agreement with political priorities , not legal obligation, 
scientific evidence, or expert judgment. That would:  
• Chill dissent and innovation  
• Deter qualified professionals from public service  
• Concentrate power in the Executive  
• Replace institutional expertise with ideological conformity  
In practice, this means public affairs officers could be fired for not echoing political talking 
points, scientists removed for reporting inconvenient findings, or regulatory experts purged 
for upholding laws the administration seeks to weaken.  
By eroding this firewall between policy implementation and political will, the proposed rule 
ignores the delicate constitutional balance between administration of the law and political 
leadership. This sets a precedent where federal employment is contingen t not on expertise 
or lawfulness, but on political loyalty , an arrangement more characteristic of authoritarian 
regimes than democratic societies.  
In a constitutional republic, the law , not the preferences of the President , must guide 
agency action. The civil service exists precisely to ensure continuity, competence, and 
accountability across changing political leadership.  
This rule would instead bring us one step closer to a patronage system that the Pendleton 
Act of 1883 , and every merit -based reform since  has sought to eliminate.  
By granting the President sweeping authority to reclassify roles into this new category, the 
regulation politicizes positions that are meant to remain nonpartisan. From regulatory 
analysts and grant administrators to public affairs officers and scientists,  a wide range of 
professionals could be targeted for their beliefs or actions  undermining the essential 
independence of federal agencies.  
This concentration of power in the executive branch is incompatible with democratic 
principles and opens the door to loyalty tests, purges, and the erosion of public trust in 
government.  
This proposed rule is not a technical reclassification ; it is a fundamental restructuring of 
the civil service that threatens the nonpartisan foundation of our federal government. It 
directly contradicts the core merit principles codified in federal law and undermines the 
very goals set forth in the April 2025 Executive Order on Restoring Equality of Opportunity 
and Meritocracy , which promotes individual merit, constitutional adherence, and equal 
treatment under the law.  
Instead of advancing those principles, this rule invites political interference, weakens legal 
safeguards, and destabilizes the institutions designed to serve the American people with 
impartiality and integrity.  
For the sake of our democracy, our public institutions, and our Constitution, I urge the 
Office of Personnel Management to rescind this rule in its entirety. At a minimum, 
substantial revisions must be made to:  
• Reinstate full due process protections for all reclassified employees  
• Limit the scope of reclassification to true political appointees  
• Ensure compliance with Title 5 merit system principles and prohibited personnel 
practices  
• Include explicit language protecting civil servants from political retaliation  
Anything less risks transforming our civil service into a tool of political enforcement . 
3. Threat to Whistleblowers and Good Governance  
One of the most alarming implications of the proposed “Schedule Policy/Career” 
classification is its potential to erode critical whistleblower protections, undermining 
ethical oversight and insulating the executive branch from lawful accountability.

I am writing to strongly oppose the proposed rule that would create a new Schedule Policy/Career category of federal employment, which would convert existing career civil service roles into effectively at-will positions. This proposal poses a direct threat to the integrity, stability, and nonpartisan nature of the federal civil service.
The current protections in place for career employees are not barriers—they are essential safeguards that ensure federal workers can carry out their duties based on evidence, expertise, and the public interest, free from political retaliation or undue influence. Removing these protections risks politicizing critical policy-making roles and undermining the impartiality that is foundational to good governance.
While misconduct and poor performance must be addressed, the existing civil service framework already provides mechanisms to do so. Weakening due process rights under the guise of improving accountability will only erode trust, morale, and institutional knowledge across federal agencies. Furthermore, conflating dissent or policy-based disagreement with "undermining the democratic process" sets a dangerous precedent that could silence experts whose perspectives are inconvenient to political leadership, regardless of merit.
The American people deserve a government led by professionals committed to law, science, and the Constitution—not one hollowed out by fear or loyalty tests. This proposal would move us in the wrong direction.
I urge OPM to withdraw this rule and instead focus on strengthening the civil service, investing in training and performance management, and protecting the nonpartisan values that have long defined federal service.

Without the safeguards of the competitive civil service system, individuals in these roles are effectively at-will employees, particularly vulnerable to leadership changes or political purges. In an administration where the president’s capacity to govern is in doubt, accepting such an appointment may mean trading long-term career stability for short-term access—an increasingly untenable tradeoff in today’s volatile climate.
